On a Wing and a Dare, what a wonderful surprise!

Posted on September 17, 2014 by Emi T

I was lucky enough to meet Linda Ulleseit, the author of On a Wing and a Dare, at a local author event last year.  Since then, she has been a gracious supporter of my series, while I’ve failed utterly to return the favor.  Now, I have FINALLY gotten a spare moment to give the first book in her Flying Horse Books series a good read, and I’m so glad that I did!

The story takes place in a mythical and equine-centric version Whales (which is plenty of reason for me to like it right away, but more on that later) where the best job in the world is to be a flying-horse rider for one of the most prominent barns.  These daring riders compete in aerial games of skill on their beautiful winged steeds, to adoration and fame.  But, despite the fact that two of the most powerful barns have been grumbling through a feud for generations, the children of these two barns are the best of friends.  Poor Emma, the charming and precocious daughter of Hoel’s barn, has her heart set on her childhood friend, Even, the handsome eldest son of Morgan’s barn.  Meanwhile, Davyd, Even’s darling and clever younger brother, is also a close friend to Emma and has developed his own feeling for her, as well.  Amid this already complex social situation, the winged horses are suddenly falling ill from a mysterious sickness.  Will Hoel and Morgan put their differences aside for the sake of their horses?  Will Emma ever be free to marry the man she truly loves?  Will sweet little Davyd ever catch a break??  You’ll just have to read for yourself to find out!

First of all, I have to say that I was sucked into the world of this story right away.  This is partly because, like many silly Americans, I often internally glamorize my English, Scottish, and Welsh roots, and lament never having the chance to visit much of the homeland.  Just as I’d hoped when first hearing that Whales was the setting of the story, Linda’s writing is flush with atmospheric details of the lofty mountains, the rolling green hills, and the wild winds.  I was delighted by how easily I found myself transported into such a vivid world.  Linda also used Welsh language in the dialog, which added a lovely flavor without ever being excluding to someone (like me) who has no knowledge of the language.  Instead, the meaning of every phrase was easy to deduce, or swiftly explained, with expert ease.  The details of the environments were also not too numerous to feel forced, but came off as natural and earnest, which can sometimes be rather rare in modern writing.

Aside from the beautiful backdrop of the story, the characters were all very well defined and interesting.  I found myself enjoying poor tortured Davyd most of all, who is expected to be a great flying-horse rider like his brother and everyone else in his family, but is terrified of heights.  How can you not instantly feel for the boy?  As Davyd struggled with his shameful secret of not actually wanting to be a rider, while also trying to reconcile his brand new feeling for his oldest friend, and nearly singlehandedly administrate the arrangements for a massive event like the annual aerial games in the midst of a equine health crisis, I found myself only caring more and more for him.  But even with my preference, I must admit that each character had a surprising amount of depth, roundness, and charming understandably.  All but Tristain, who’s really just a jerk.  But then, the strength of my dislike for him is only a credit to the author.  Love and hate both require equal skill to produce in a reader.

So, if you can’t afford a vacation to Whales, or if you just want to read a well written, exciting, and truly charming book, then I highly recommend On a Wing and a Dare.  I never thought I would so enjoy a YA book about flying horses, and I’m delighted to find that I was so wrong.  I can’t wait to read the rest of the series as well!  Even if this story isn’t your usual genre, trust me.  It’s worth giving it a try.

Get the eBook  on Amazon, or on Smashwords.  Only $2.99!  The paperback is also available on Amazon.

Check out the series on Goodreads.

Follow Linda Ulleseit on her blog, Twitter, or Facebook.

Suggested Reading: The Maltese Falcon by Dashiell Hammett

Posted on September 14, 2014 by Emi T

See?  I told you it wasn’t all gonna be steampunk now.

I adore classic lit.  If they’ve made a massively iconic film of it in the 30s – 60s, if it appears on the “100 books to read before you die” lists, if I can find a battered old paperback of it that’s older than I am, I want to read it.  I think that tendency comes partly from the fact that I didn’t go to a typical high school.  As a kid, I was never forced to read anything, but my family and friend made the classics sound grand, beautiful, and mysterious.  Once I got a taste for them, I now always look to the past to find something great to read.

This month, I read The Maltese Falcon by Hammett.  I read The Thin Man earlier, and loved it, so why not try the big one?  Well, let me tell you, diving into Hammett’s world of noir isn’t like watching the movies.  Now, I love a Boggie movie any day, and William Powell is precisely what I look for in a man, so don’t get me wrong.  I love the movies that they’ve done with Hammett’s books, but the two versions are drastically different for many reasons.

First and foremost, Hammett’s writing style is singular.  I’ve read Chandler and others in the “hardball PI” genre, but I’ve never read anything like Hammett.  Reading this book, I was stunned by the fact that Sam Spades’s actions were never explained at all.  He often did things that confused me, or seemed unfeeling and cruel, and I was never given a single moment of explanation or excuse.  When Sherlock Holmes goes out in a hurry dressed at a vicar, and then comes home covered in blood at 3am, he always has a chance to explain what happened, and how it will help his case.  This is not the case with Sam Spade.  I was left with a vague uneasiness as I tried to guess his reasoning, and honestly, I find the man to be nearly as off-putting and frightening as Uriah Heep.

But even with this lack of explanation and emotional connection to the character, I couldn’t say that Sam didn’t feel completely real to me.  In fact, he felt more solid, whole, and real to me because he acted so independently, and because he was so damned unnerving.  Reading about him was like following a sociopath around all day.  When I re-watched the movie recently, I was stunned by how intrinsically likable and sympathetic the character became in Bogart’s hands.  The Sam of the movie and the Sam of the book are vastly different people, and I’m glad they are.  While I’m sitting here in awe of the response Hammett was able to get from me, I honestly don’t believe that the movie would have become such an icon if Boggie hadn’t played him the way he did.

Other than Sam, there were a lot of differences between the movie that we all know, and the book that few have actually read.  One thing that surprised me was the clear evidence that Joel Cairo was meant to be gay.  However, nothing was said outright about it, and Joel wasn’t treated like any more of a caricature than the other characters.  He was simply more interested in the young gunman than he was in Bridget, which explained why she wasn’t able to seduce him the way she could with every other man she met.  Considering the times, I can easily understand why all of those tells were removed from the script.  It only makes the book that much more edgy for it’s time, which it was clearly meant to be.

Another thing that I found incredible about this book was the fact that no one in it ever said what they meant, and yet I was able to understand their true intentions easily.  Everyone, of course, but Sam who confused me consistently.  That kind of writing is risky because it’s easy for the reader to miss what’s really going on.  I really respect Hammett’s confidence to keep to this style, without a moment of hesitation.  Although most people in The Thin Man said exactly what they meant, in that book Hammett employed an equally brazen style that could have–but didn’t–go horribly wrong.  I get the feeling that each on of his books was an experiment in pushing the limits of writing.

In the end, I’m very happy I actually read this book, instead of just watching the movie.  I feel like I learned a lot about humanity, greed, desperation, and the high-art of writing a damn good book.  If you haven’t read this one, grab a copy and start reading it today.  Every second-hand bookshop in town is bound to have a few dog-eared copies on the shelf.

You can find The Maltese Falcon on Goodreads, and Amazon.

For free eye-candy, Google Image Search The Maltese Falcon.

All images from Wikipedia Commons.

and, We’re back! … sort of…

Posted on September 7, 2014 by Emi T

White Rabbit concept art by michael kutsche © Disney Enterprises Inc

Hello, lovelies!  Sorry about stepping out like that.  Right after I put this blog on pause, the chaos in my life intensified exponentially.  Typical, right?  Not to whine, and not to go into too much detail, I had a failed surgery, then a much better one that fixed the problem, lost two dear friends suddenly and in the space of a week, lost my job, got another job and then lost that very quickly.  When I paused the blog, I was only expecting the surgery part, not any of the rest.  Now that things have calmed down somewhat, I’m starting to get my feet back under me.  My family and I went to the circus just for the hell of it, went to see our favorite comedian preform, and I went to see Guardians of the Galaxy a few times too.  It’s funny how sometimes even the silliest and more trivial things can trigger true healing, isn’t it?  And so, here I am.  Still a bit dizzy, but back in the world!  lol

In the meantime, all things Twist have been progressing nicely.  Honestly, Twist was the only thing I wanted to work on through all of my troubles.  It was just a nice, cozy place to be.  Book 3 is in final edits as we speak, and I’m nearly finished with the cover design!  I’m so excited to show you all!  I’ll have a preview of the cover up soon, along with the first 3 chapters, as usual.  Stay tuned!

Jeffery is also starting to get some attention as well, which pleases me greatly.  The 11th chapter of his little story will go live on Thursday, and all the previous chapters are still available to enjoy.  I’m going to leave that book on his blog indefinitely, as a forever freebie, just for you.  But I’ll also be releasing it as an eBook and paperback as well, at the lowest price The Great And Powerful Amazon will allow.

Other than all of that, I discovered something magical!  Have you ever used IFTTT?  It’s amazing.  I’m probably going to do a whole blog post about it soon, and how I’m using it’s awesome might to my own ends.  In the meantime, check out my Tumblr, Twitter, and Facebook for daily visual treats.  And that’s all I’ll say for now…

Lastly, I’d like to mention that I’m going to be changing things up a little around here.  You might see less pure steampunk things in the future.  Following a single theme was very helpful for me as I learned the art of blogging and social mediaing, but now it’s becoming restrictive.  There’s plenty of beauty and great stories in the world, outside of one genre.  I’ll still be sharing lots of Victorian goodies and as many pretty pocket watches as I can find, but there were be less steamy items as well.

Thanks for sticking around, while I dealt with my issues.  You guys are the best!

Taking a holiday.

Posted on August 4, 2014 by Emi T

Jules Férat, 1875, from www.julesvernebooks.com

Hello, lovelies.  I can’t blame my blog on missing a post yesterday, or the lesser content that I’ve had to offer recently.  Like a sagging dirigible in a gale, I’m simply getting a bit swamped by my life and things are starting to slip through my rigging.

I want to write interesting, engaging posts, and share wonderful shiny things, and keep a real sense of delight in this blog.  At the moment, however, I find I simply don’t have the time and energy needed to keep this blog running at the level that I want.

So, for the time being, I’ve decided to take a short holiday from this blog so that I might recollect myself, get my ducks in a row, and all of that.  Don’t worry about the progress of the novels.  Writing is still my first priority.  The 3rd novel in the Clockwork Twist series is still set for release in November this year, I’ve just finished the first draft of the 7th book, and I’m beginning to work on the 8th now.

To tide you over in the meantime, I encourage you to check out The Journals of Jeffery Simian over on Jeffery’s blog.  The first serialized novelette is already running, with 5 whole chapters available for your reading pleasure right now, and new chapters each week!  It’s a fun little romp through the Clockwork Twist universe, from the perspective of our favorite gentlemanly baboon.  Travel to a circus made entirely of ice and battle winter faeries with Jeffery and Idris, his faithful djinn companion.  It’s good fun.

Over the next little while, I will endeavor to bring this blog back to glory!  Be sure to follow me on Twitter, Facebook, or Tumblr, to be notified the moment this thing goes back online.  I wish you a glorious day, and a bright future to come.

See you soon.

Shiny new servers, and a monkey on a mission!

Posted on July 3, 2014 by Emi T

I hope that you haven’t noticed yet, but this site is now being hosted by a different company.  How exciting!  There wasn’t anything wrong with my old hosting service, and I hope there are no hard feelings, but I seem to have a great deal more control on this new service.  Still, I’ve never moved a site before, and I’m not sure that everything is exactly as it should be…

So, if you happen to notice anything odd or amiss at all, or (heaven forbid) hit a 404 or some such horror, please do let me know in the comments down below.  (checks to make sure the comments are still available.)  I’ll get to fixing any last minute issues as quickly as I can.

Meanwhile, it’s July, the 3rd.  You know what that means, don’t you?  That’s right, today is the first day of the Jeffery Simian serial adventures!!  The first post is up as of right now!  Click here or click on the monkey head to go check it out.

And of course, keep your eyes peeled for the following entries as they appear, each Thursday at noon, pst, until mid September.

Happy adventuring!
